content.content: Hey everyone, We built Oasis on IPFS and would like to transfer the website to a .crypto blockchain domain. The Maker Foundation is excited about this, but wants the community to make the ultimate decision on the domain name! Here are some suggestions but feel free to drop your ideas in the comments:  Daicommunity.crypto Makercommunity.crypto Welovedai.crypto  Why is this important?  Puts the DAO in charge of the Oasis App instead of any one person It would give users the ability to interact with Oasis in the case the website servers were attacked or removed by a third party It would give users the ability to interact with Oasis in the case oasis.app was seized by the domain registrar  Please let us know if you have any questions, we would be happy to answer them!

Maybe this is too obvious to be worth mentioning. oasis.crypto?     MagoCrypto:  Puts the DAO in charge of the Oasis App instead of any one person   Also, I will say that this is more complex than just putting it on IPFS. If the DAO is in charge of the Oasis App that implies input into the direction, funding, development, etc. Previously the community has not had responsibility for these things and I’m not necessarily sure that the community wants responsibility for Oasis in its current form. When Black Thursday happened, this was one of the reasons I didn’t personally feel that MKR Holders had the lions share of the responsibility. If we did take responsibility for the frontend, that would change.

In my understanding, they are simply mirroring the Oasis code (which is open source and licensed under GPL, the Oasis brand is NOT open source) on IPFS. The community would own the domain, not Oasis, as this would be an independent brand and front-end. I could be wrong though - @MagoCrypto should specify

Fair enough, my mistake on the Oasis brand.     g_dip:  The community would own the domain, not Oasis, as this would be an independent brand and front-end.   I’m not sure this is something that we want. I’d love for a mirror of it to be available, but I don’t think the DAO should be taking responsibility for the mirror.

While I’m sure the community member proposing this wants to work with the DAO in doing this, it raises the interesting question of whether the DAO can actually stop someone from transferring a tokenized domain into its control  … beyond my technical comprehension unfortunately.

g_dip:  While I’m sure the community member proposing this wants to work with the DAO in doing this, it raises the interesting question of whether the DAO can actually stop someone from transferring a tokenized domain into its control   Great question. I also have no idea how this would work. Do companies in the real world have to deal with the same issue of ‘poisoned gifts?’ Not saying that this is an example, but people must have tried to transfer ownership of stuff to companies with the intention of negatively affecting them?
makerdao.crypto Is it already taken ? Seems the more obvious to me
The community would own the domain, not Oasis, as this would be an independent brand and front-end.  Yes, this is correct.
oasis.crypto?  We think it’s best to distinguish this app from the app that’s run by the Maker foundation. We want non-Oasis related branding.
makervaults.crypto? I would avoid the word community, it isn’t a forum or chat server or anything.

I realize that you are just doing IPFS for now, but can the same .crypto domain name point to Swarm too? If we need a different URL for Swarm, maybe we can reserve it now so it can be mostly the same? For example, if makerdao.crypto then also makerdao.eth ?
I Vote for Welovedai.crypto I believe it’s time for the Community to understand that we are the DAO and we need to put the DAO in charge of many things including but not limited to the Oasis App.
I agree with welovedai.crypto +1 Also would love to not see it blocked for Venezuela

Okey, let’s not jump too fast. I would appreciate if more information would be provided:  what is IPFS who is ‘we’ what is ‘.crypto’ blockchain domain how is this code deployed (who does it, who owns, how do you verify what code are you loading etc…)
I would go for makerdao.com/eth/crypto with subdomains for our differents apps. Maybe even simply maker.com/eth/cypto if it’s not too expensive. But big question ho will manage that? A Web Domain?

I think this is a really smart idea, but is there any reason why we would want to use Unstoppable Domains .crypto domains over the Ethereum Name Service .eth domains? It seems the latter has more adoption and works natively with metamask. Regardless of the path, it think it’s important to have something like this to decentralize maker at all levels.

IPFS is a decentralized storage network Unstoppable Domains, a domain registry that launches domains on blockchains .crypto a NFT on Ethereum. It can be used to simplify payments and to launch censorship-resistant websites. The domain is on the blockchain and the content is on IPFS. We developed the first version from the open-source code and we’re asking the community to take ownership to make future updates.

So, you are speaking on behalf of Unstoppable Domains. I am just trying to understand how exactly does this work.  how does the browser know it has to switch to ipfs protocol (do all major browsers support it?) who serves the blockchain data where the data pointing to the “ipfs naming scheme” (hash) is written how browser initially finds the entity that serves this data who will deploy frontend code and update the blockchain domain how can we easily verify the code matches the github release (presumably tagged) does that mean that MF’s Oasis website and community website won’t necessarily be in sync? Is this a problem? what is the yearly cost of domain ownership

The plan is to have an alternative version of Oasis on the decentralized web using a blockchain domain and decentralised storage network. If makerdao.com is seized or down for some reason, the subdomains would be down too. So it would be good to have an alternative version on dweb that is always accessible and managed by the community.

Glad to you like the idea! You are free to use both domain extension. We thought it would be cool to gift the Maker community a .crypto domain and it would be forever owned by them without renewal fees. .crypto will be eventually supported by all wallets and browsers, we’re actively working on it,.

Correct Browsers are natively integrating support for blockchain domains and the ability to serve IPFS content. The browser. Browser sees a .crypto domain, reads the Ethereum blockchain, finds the IPFS hash associated with the domain, and serves the content. We’re happy to make updates upon request going forward. However, if someone from the community wanted to do it, that would also be great. We can share the code. Possibly not - they’re going to be run separately. We’re happy to help with updates based on what MF pushes No renewal fees, .crypto domains are forever owned!

jernejml:  how does the browser know it has to switch to ipfs protocol (do all major browsers support it?)   Not yet for most browsers. But it’s perhaps interesting that Brave has very recently announced its native support for IPFS. You just type ipfs://address  (it’s a hash, I believe)  and it opens.    reddit    r/BATProject - IPFS support lands in Brave browser on the Nightly channel 82 votes and 19 comments so far on Reddit

MagoCrypto:  Browsers are natively integrating support for blockchain domains and the ability to serve IPFS content.   Browsers are not  (full) ethereum nodes. Even if they have client code (like web3.js), they need to connect to something, right? Is this centralized service?     MagoCrypto:  Browser sees a .crypto domain, reads the Ethereum blockchain, finds the IPFS hash associated with the domain, and serves the content.   how does browser distinguish between (root) top domain and blockchain domain? Is “.crypto” actually hardcoded on their blockchain whitelist? I am confused.     iammeeoh:  But it’s perhaps interesting that Brave has very recently announced its native support for IPFS. You just type ipfs://address (it’s a hash, I believe) and it opens.   Yeah, but this happens if user explicitly provides protocol name.  This can only work when clicking on links. Non-tech users won’t specify protocol names, when typing to address bar.

Browsers are not (full) ethereum nodes. Even if they have client code (like web3.js), they need to connect to something, right? Is this centralized service?  Most browsers are using services to read the Ethereum blockchain like Infura. This is similar to most applications in Ethereum. There are, however, multiple services that a browser could use. Eventually, we imagine that browsers will integrate things like Ethereum light clients  how does browser distinguish between (root) top domain and blockchain domain? Is “.crypto” actually hardcoded on their blockchain whitelist? I am confused.  Yes, they hardcode the blockchain domain registries and read from IPFS instead of regular DNS when they see these.  Yeah, but this happens if user explicitly provides protocol name. This can only work when clicking on links. Non-tech users won’t specify protocol names, when typing to address bar.  The IPFS integration with Brave will make a feature like this even more interesting. Users can type in a .crypto domain and then navigate to an IPFS hash using the IPFS node. We agree that it’s unlikely the feature will be used if people need to put ipfs hashes directly into the browser. That’s why we built human readable names.

Here are the domain ideas we’ve collected so far:   oasis.crypto - We think it’s best to distinguish this app from the app that’s run by the Maker foundation, so we want non-Oasis related branding.  makerdao.crypto - This domain is already taken  makervaults.crypto - This domain is already taken  Welovedai.crypto +1 vote - This domain is available!  makerdao.com/eth/crypto or maker.com/eth/crypto - These would not be blockchain domains because they do not use the .crypto domain name.  Are there any other suggestions for DAI-related domain names? Happy to answer any outstanding questions about blockchain domain names and websites on IPFS.

MagoCrypto:  Yes, they hardcode the blockchain domain registries and read from IPFS instead of regular DNS when they see these.   This seems complicated. If i know right people at mozilla, they can put ‘.jernejml’ to the whitelist? Does this mean that different browsers can potentially redirect to different protocols? Seems quite a security issue. Also, i am not very fond of ‘.crypto’ domain, would prefer something like ‘.finance’ or ‘.defi’

This seems complicated. If i know right people at mozilla, they can put ‘.jernejml’ to the whitelist? Does this mean that different browsers can potentially redirect to different protocols? Seems quite a security issue. Also, i am not very fond of ‘.crypto’ domain, would prefer something like ‘.finance’ or ‘.defi’  It’s not complicated. It’s just a way to route traffic to blockchain lookups for blockchain registries and regular DNS for those. Browsers will not easily add support for any alternate registries. They will only do it if they think it is a standard. Collisions from multiple protocols are not a risk because browsers will only adopt when it’s a standard.  Crypto has already achieved this and is being supported by several browsers (coming soon). .Crypto has over 300K domain registrations. It’s the largest blockchain domain registry.  We think it would be really cool to showcase the maker app as part of an upcoming browser launch. What do you think?

Happy New Year! It looks like Welovedai.crypto is both available and has the most votes. Is there an admin(s) we can connect with to discuss transferring this blockchain domain and website built on IPFS to the MakerDAO community? Thanks in advance!
